abstract.text: A CarPlay scene that controls your app’s user interface.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A scene manages your app’s user interface, including the window that CarPlay displays from that scene. Only navigation apps have access to that window, and use it for drawing map content. All other categories of apps use the scene’s interface controller exclusively for constructing their user interfaces.

The scene manages the display of the window on the vehicle’s CarPlay screen, and the life cycle of that scene as CarPlay and the user interact with it. The scene notifies its delegate—an object that conforms to
—about various state changes and user actions.
You don’t create scenes directly. Instead, you specify the name of the appropriate scene class as part of the CarPlay scene configuration you add to your
file—see the example below—or that you return from your app delegate’s

code: <!-- Specify the name of the scene class. -->

abstract.text: Integrate CarPlay in apps related to audio, communication, navigation, parking, EV charging, food ordering, and more.
A controller that manages the templates for constructing a scene’s user interface.
An object that provides vehicle properties and configuration for the CarPlay environment.
A CarPlay scene that controls your app’s user interface.
The window that belongs to the scene.
The object that receives the scene’s life-cycle events.
The controller that manages the scene’s user interface.
The methods for responding to the life cycle events of your app’s scene.
A window that displays its content on the CarPlay screen.
Use scenes to present your app’s content on the vehicle’s built-in screen.
Configure your CarPlay-enabled app with the entitlements it requires.
Make your CarPlay-enabled apps compatible with older system versions, such as iOS 13 and earlier.
Configure Simulator to run and debug your CarPlay-enabled app.
Retrieves the configuration data for UIKit to use when creating a new scene.
An object that represents one instance of your app’s user interface.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
